text: hello and welcome to cupcake addictions
handbag or purse cupcake tutorial we'll
be showing you how to make this great
little Chanel handbag cupcake I first
thought this idea in the book cupcakes
cookies and pie-o-my by Karen tak and
Alan Richardson and I knew that I had to
do a tutorial on them because they are
amazing there's quite a lot to this
tutorial so let's get started
tools and equipment that we will be
using today I have two cupcakes rather
than the standard one I've got a pair of
scissors I've got a butter knife as well
as a serrated edge knife so just two
knives that I've got a quilting tool if
you're not familiar with what a quilting
tool is looks like this it's got a
little wheel on the end of it a metal
wheel with tiny little teeth that rolls
around these come in most sewing kits
they're not expensive you can find them
in the sewing section of the supermarket
I've got a spoon I've got a half portion
of our modeling chocolate modeling
chocolate recipe and tutorial is on our
channel if you're looking for how to
make that I've tinted mine a lovely
light pink Chanel pink I like to call it
now a batch of our modeling chocolate is
going to do approximately six of these
cupcakes so if you want to do a dozen in
all this color you'll need a double
batch of that modeling chocolate
pre-prepared I've got some of our
perfectly pipeable buttercream frosting
I've got some melted white chocolate
I've got some soft eating licorice do
make sure that it's the soft dating
liquorice not the hard licorice twists
you can tell that it's soft eating when
you push it with your fingers you'll see
that it pushes out of shape I've got a
few little pink cashews or little pink
shiny balls that I'm going to use for
the clasps I've got three different
circle cutters the sizes that I'm using
today I've got the smaller is a 2
centimetre or 3/4 inch the medium is a 3
centimeter or one and a quarter inch and
the largest is a 5 point 5 centimeter or
a 2 inch cookie cutter if you don't have
circle cutters at home I suggest you get
a set they're really handy but if you
don't have them think about the things
that you do have in your kitchen that
you could use the larger one is about
the circumference of a champagne flute
and the two small
it could be the insides and the outsides
of different piping tips or other things
that you might have around the kitchen
I've also got a couple of cocktail
sticks or toothpicks and I've got some
licorice strap so these are sold
generally by the meter and they're just
a bit of black licorice sold at a firm
strap let's get started firstly we're
going to take our two cupcakes choose
which one you think's got the better
looking patty pan or cupcake case on the
bottom and unwrap the other one let's
take some of that melted white chocolate
I'm just using white because it's the
closest color to the pink that I'm using
on there the modeling chocolate so it
blends quite well just dab that on top
now you can see that my two cupcakes are
both quite flat on top if you do have a
high dome on your cupcakes just trim it
off with that serrated edge knife so
you've got two quite flat surfaces to
stick together and just sandwich them
together they should look something like
this now that's going to go into the
freezer for about 15 minutes and we're
going to let that white chocolate seal
really set and then we'll come back and
get carving okay so that one's been in
the freezer for about 15 minutes you can
see that nice chocolate seal is really
hard so I'm going to take the serrated
edge knife and I'm just going to trim
this cupcake into a sort of a handbag
shape so I'm going about 1/2 an inch
from the edge of the cupcake and I'm
going in a downward angle all the way
out to the outer edge of that bottom of
that cupcake I should say the top
upside-down and then again on the other
side and I like to just take a little
bit off the corners as well just to give
them that nice rounded shape and a
little off each edge don't want it to be
too sharp
should have something that looks like
this so now I'm going to take some of
that buttercream I'm using our perfectly
pipeable buttercream frosting but you
could just use tinned frosting for this
doesn't really matter this is just going
to act like a little bit of a crumb coat
so you're just putting a very thin layer
of the frosting on and pushing it into
that top cupcake and that's just going
to keep any crumbs at bay should be nice
and easy to frost because it's been
frozen that top cupcake will be nice and
firm so your crumb shouldn't be going
too far anyway you can see I've but a
little bit of a gap just here
so I'm going to just spread some
frosting in there as well just to even
it up try not to get frosting on the
outside of your patty pan your cupcake
taste you really want to try and keep
that nice and clean and before we pop it
back in the freezer just scrape off any
excess because you do want to retain
that lovely shape of the handbag that
you've just carved lovely so when your
cupcake looks like this it's time to go
back into the freezer for another 5
minutes just to firm up that base coat
of frosting okay so my cupcakes been in
the freezer for about 10 minutes it's
not frozen but it is quite firm and that
crumb coat lovely and set now I've had a
bit of a tidy up well that's been in the
freezer you want a nice clean work
surface because it's time to roll out
our liquorice to make the Chanel logos
the reason I love soft eating licorice
as opposed to black fondant you can use
either but soft eating licorice rolls a
little bit firmer than black fondant but
it's really readily available and you
can use it in such tiny amounts so if
you just want a little bit of it to a
bit of detail work or to pop a little
Chanel logo on a handbag you can take it
out of the cupboard you can use it as
much as you like and then pop a seal on
it and stick it back in the cupboard
ready for the next time so you can see
that as I'm rolling that I'm just
turning it over that's so that I don't
develop too much of a bend in it and I
want to make sure that I roll it out too
so that it's big enough for two of my
medium-sized cookie cutters to sit in so
I'm happy that's a good size
now I'm going to take the medium cookie
cutter circle cutter and I'm just going

smaller circle so what you should have

another great thing about black licorice
is it actually holds its shape a lot
better than fondant wood springs back
into shape or you going to take the

little areas to make that a C so I'm
cutting out just a small them out there
and on a slight angle you can see there
I'm not cutting out very much at all but
as I cut it you'll notice cut it out on
a slight angle those are going to be our
little Chanel logo loop and through each
other ready to go onto our handbag now
I've pre-rolled out that modeling
chocolate great things about modeling
chocolate is it doesn't need to be
rolled immediately before you want to
use it because it doesn't dry out like
fondant does so I've rolled out a piece
it's about 18 by 22 centimeters the
equivalent is 7 inch by 9 inch and we're
going to place that over top of the

give the cupcake another coat of
frosting we've already got that lovely

give us a lovely soft and sticky surface
to attach that modeling chocolate to
once again make sure that you just scoop

off all right now I do do this

something to stick to
now I'm just going to lay this piece
it's quite a bit more than I need but
I'm just going to lay it over the top
and just smooth down the top of the bag

probably the fiddly ax start here

I'm going to tap that modeling chocolate

there's our top flat and just push it

all the way around
